entry.title: MFE Evaluation
entry.content:
Introduction

I'm curious about the ranking of those popular graduate programs in the United States about quantitative finance. The data includes information of 16 quant master programs, which is collected from , and universities official websites. My criterion of judging a program is divided into two categories. 1. On-campus benefit

  • Class size \((-)\)
  • International student rate \((-)\)
  • Lecturer-to-student ratio
  • Industry lecturer percentage
  1. Post-master achievement
  • Wage
  • Percentage in asset management

To interpret, considering that information asymmetry is largely reduced for local residents, a low international student rate can be interpreted as the program's more welcomed by local residents, and thus higher probability to be satisfying.

The difference in employment rate is not significant, so we ignore it. In deciding career in finance, investment banking stands for the sell side, and asset management/hedge fund for the buy side. Commonly buy side enjoys better treatment and working environment, and graduate students often need to work in sell side for several years before entering buy side market. Therefore the programs' student percentage employed in asset management directly after graduation is a nice indicator for evaluation.(It doesn't mean working in investment banks sucks, instead they're well paid and cool. But they're too busy and lack leisure, which fit me bad.)

Methods and Approach

We used the Technique for Order Preference by Similarity to Ideal Solution (TOPSIS) method to apply the indicators above. This method takes advantage of solid data and avoid mistakes by subjective judgements. The process is explained as follows.

TOPSIS

  1. Normalization We first normalized the minimization indicators to make them all positively oriented. In our case it's \(I_1\) and \(I_2\).

\[ \max -x \]

  1. Construct an evaluation matrix Next, we construct a comprehensive evaluation matrix using the normalized data.

\[ X=\begin{bmatrix} x_{11} & x_{12} & \cdots & x_{1m}\\ x_{21} & x_{22} & \cdots & x_{2m}\\ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ x_{n1} & x_{n2} & \cdots & x_{nm} \end{bmatrix} \]

  1. Standardization We standardize the matrix to eliminate the influence of dimensions.

\[ Z=\begin{bmatrix} z_{11} & z_{12} & \cdots & z_{1m}\\ z_{21} & z_{22} & \cdots & z_{2m}\\ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ z_{n1} & z_{n2} & \cdots & z_{nm} \end{bmatrix} \]

The values of each element are as follows:

\[ z_{ij}=\frac{x_{ij}}{\sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^nx_{ij}^2}} \]

Entropy Weight Method

It's important to determine the weights of each element \(z_{ij}\). The traditional methods are often subjective, such as the Delphi method and the Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP). Although these methods are mature in practice, they still cannot avoid the problem of subjectivity. Therefore, we considered Entropy Weight Method (EWM) for objective analysis.

  1. Information Entropy Formula The intuition is, the greater information entropy, the smaller the probability of event occurring, and the less information is known. Therefore, a smaller weight should be assigned. Conversely, the smaller the information entropy, the less unknown information and the more known information, and a higher weight should be assigned.

\[ H(X)=\sum_{i=1}^np(x_i)I(x_i)=-\sum_{i=1}^np(x_i)\log(p(x_i)) \]

  1. Max-Min Standardization Since the probability is always non-negative, it is necessary to perform \(\max-\min\) standardization on the original data so that the values are in the range of \([0,1]\).

\[ z_{ij}=\frac{x_{ij}-\min\{x_{1j},\cdots,x_{nj}\}}{\max\{x_{1j},\cdots,x_{nj}\}-\min\{x_{1j},\cdots,x_{nj}\}} \]

  1. Construction of Standardization Matrix

Where \(z_{ij}\) represents the value of the \(i-th\) object after normalization and standardization under the \(j-th\) indicator.

\[ Z=\begin{bmatrix} z_{11} & z_{12} & \cdots & z_{1m}\\ z_{21} & z_{22} & \cdots & z_{2m}\\ \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\ z_{n1} & z_{n2} & \cdots & z_{nm} \end{bmatrix} \]

  1. Information Entropy Determined

The probability function \(p(x)\) of the event is:

\[ p_{ij}=\frac{z_{ij}}{\sum_{i=1}^nz_{ij}} \]

For the \(j-th\) indicator, the information entropy expression is:

\[ e_j=-\frac{1}{\log n}\sum_{i=1}^np_{ij}\log (p_{ij}) \]

  1. Allocating Weights Since the larger the value of information entropy, the smaller the weight allocated, the information entropy needs to be positively oriented, and the weight \(W_j\) is obtained through normalization.

\[ d_j=1-e_j \]

\[ W_j=\frac{d_j}{\sum_{j=1}^md_j} \]

Using R code, the weight of LS rate and wage are

\(I_1\) \(I_2\) \(I_3\) \(I_4\) \(I_5\) \(I_6\)
0.0850 0.1689 0.2758 0.1609 0.1508 0.1585

Scores

After standardizing the indicators in the matrix \(Z\), we found the maximum and minimum values of each column vector and denoted them as \(Z^+\) and \(Z^-\). The TOPSIS method determines the evaluation score of each object based on its relative and absolute score in the dataset, taking into account the weights assigned to each indicator. Consider a Euclidean space derived through evaluation set, the distance between object i and the upper/lower boundaries in the space are respectively as followed:

\[ D^{+}=\sqrt{\sum_{j=1}^mw_j(Z^{+}_j-z_{ij})^2} \]

\[ D^{-}=\sqrt{\sum_{j=1}^mw_j(Z^{-}_j-z_{ij})^2} \]

The non-normalized comprehensive evaluation score of object \(i\) is: After normalization, we obtained the comprehensive evaluation score of each object. Using R programming, we visualize the scores.

Pton Baruch UCB NCState Cornell CMU UCLA Columbia
0.1452 0.0533 0.1244 0.0495 0.0740 0.0787 0.0647 0.0734
JHU NYU GIT Fordham UW Boston SBU RU
0.0639 0.0586 0.0443 0.0293 0.0147 0.0906 0.0070 0.0285

We can see that, Master in Finance of Princeton and Master of Financial Engineering of UC Berkeley, are both top programs for quant, which is a result similar with . From a geographic point of view, we discovered that most programs located in the northeast of US. Another thing that I questioned about is whether better school title provides better program. This diagram gives a absolute ``yes'', for the programs score above 0.05 are all from universities rank top 30 in USNews. So it's still necessary to earn a better school title, no matter where you're working at.

Several Curious Questions

We've finished the job of valuing whether a program is good or not. We used certain information such as class size, initial wages, etc. There're some other important information not used for evaluating the program, more like the property of the program itself. We draw several curious questions from the observed data, and we use linear regression model to find out why.

  1. Does tuition fee worth it?
  2. Does lower acceptance rate make the program better?
  3. What makes student acceptance rate differs?

Tuition Fee

We apply the simple linear regression here. \[ Y= \beta_0+\beta_1X+\varepsilon \] In this case, \(X\) denotes the and \(Y\) denotes . We can regress on . \[ \texttt{Scores}\approx \beta_0+\beta_1\times \texttt{Fee} \] We find out whether score and fee hold some kind of relationship by doing hypothesis testing, the null hypothesis and alternative hypothesis are as follow. \[ H_0: X, Y \text{ have no relationship} \] \[ H_1: X, Y \text{ have some relationship} \] Mathematically, this is equivalent to test

\[ H_0:\beta_1=0\qquad H_1:\beta_1\neq 0 \]

In practice, we use t-statistic to test hypothesis, where \[ t=\frac{\hat{\beta}_1-0}{SE(\hat{\beta}_1)} \]

The p-value reflects the probability that t-statistic is more extreme comparing with the observed statistic, under \(H_0\) is true. A small p-value shows that it's less possible that \(H_0\) is true. In this case p-value is extremely close to \(0\), so we have much evidence to reject \(H_0\). Therefore there's positive relationship between tuition fee and program score.

Estimate SE t value P-value
Intercept -2.614e-02 8.180e-03 -3.196 0.0064
Fee 1.152e-06 9.936e-08 11.599 \(<0.0001\)

To examine how well the model fits, we test \(RSE\) and \(R^2\).

Value
RSE 0.01167
\(R^2\) 0.9057

Where RSE stands for residual standard error, which estimates the standard error of \(\varepsilon\) in equation \((1)\).

\[ RSE=\sqrt{\frac{1}{n-2}RSS}=\sqrt{\frac{1}{n-2} \sum_{i=1}^n(y_i-\hat{y}_i)^2} \]

While \(R^2\) measures the proportion of variability in that can be explained by . In this case \(R^2 = 0.91\), which is significant. \[ R^2=1-\frac{TSS}{RSS}=1-\frac{\sum_{i=1}^n(y_i-\hat{y}_i)^2}{\sum_{i=1}^n(y_i-\bar{y})^2} \]

Acceptance

We do the same t-test on acceptance rate, and found it has negative relationship with score at the significance level \(\alpha=0.05\). But the \(R^2\) is only 0.3902, not so significant for fitting, probably resulted in the small dataset.

Estimate SE t value P-value
Intercept 0.09478 0.01309 7.240 \(<0.0001\)
Acceptance -0.10330 0.03451 -2.993 0.00958

The result is consistent with the intuition. Programs with lower acceptance rate tends to be strict and professional, and that's often a reason for high score rating.

Student Acceptance

Program application is two-sided: when being choosed by universities, students also choose programs after getting lots of offers. We're interested how student acceptance rate is affected.

Intuitively, students are willing to enroll in programs with high score. Besides, programs that give less offers will be scarce resource in the education market, and students might have larger burdens to turn them off.

\[ \texttt{Stu.accept}\approx\beta_0+\beta_1\times \texttt{Score}+\beta_2\times \texttt{Acceptance} \]

We make hypothesis \[ H_0: \beta_1=\beta_2=0 \] \[ H_1: \text{At least one }\beta_i\neq 0, i=1,2 \] The hypothesis in this case is test by F-statistic: \[ F=\frac{(TSS-RSS)/p}{RSS/(n-p-1)} \] If the linear regression is correct, we have \[ E \left[\frac{1}{n-p-1}RSS\right]=\sigma^2 \] If hypothesis \(H_0\) is also true, we'll have \[ E \left[ \frac{1}{p}(TSS-RSS)\right]=\sigma^2 \] Therefore F-statistic will be close to 1 if is not related to and . On the other hand, as the F-statistic goes larger, we have more evidence to reject \(H_0\).

Estimate SE t value P-value
Intercept 0.6866 0.2042 3.363 0.00509
Score -0.2169 1.9135 -0.113 0.91148
Acceptance -0.5218 0.3164 -1.649 0.12309
Value
RSE 0.2125
\(R^2\) 0.2396
F-statistic 2.049
p-value 0.1685

F-statistic under significance level \(\alpha=0.05\) and degree of freedom 2,13 is \(F_{0.95,2,13}=3.81\), the critical region is: \[ C=\{F:F\geqslant F_{0.95,2,13}\} \]

Since \(F=2.049\notin \mathcal{C}\), we cannot reject null hypothesis. This result can also be derived by taking the advantage of p-value \(0.1685>0.05=\alpha\).

The curious thing that contradict with intuition is that both score and acceptance rate don't affect much on student's dicision in enroll in or not.

But it's interesting that if we consider the interaction part, the model will fit much better.

Estimate SE t value P-value
Intercept 0.55442 0.18075 3.067 0.00977
Acceptance 0.05029 0.35328 0.142 0.88916
Score 3.03355 2.08236 1.457 0.17084
Acc.:Sc. -16.92481 6.81917 -2.482 0.02885
Value
RSE 0.1798
\(R^2\) 0.4976
F-statistic 3.961
p-value 0.03555

The null hypothesis is rejected under \(\alpha=0.05\), checked equivalently by critical region and p-value.

Conclusion

We first ranked the 16 most popular master program about quant. The top two are Master of Finance from Pton and Master of Financial Engineering from UCB.

Through linear regression model, we find out that the level of program is postively related to tuition fee, and negatively related to programs' acceptance rate. The result is backed by t-test on the significance level of 0.05. Next we use multi-variable linear regression and F-test, and find out that the students' acceptance rate is unrelated to the programs' score and acceptance rate, but weakly related if the interaction part is considered.

Interactions occur when the effect of one independent variable on the dependent variable depends on the value of another independent variable. In other words, the relationship between the dependent variable and one independent variable changes depending on the value of another independent variable. This means that there still exist some unknown independent variables other than programs' score and acceptance rate that affect students' accepting rate. The work of finding the unknown variable is not done in this project, which can be improved by later studies.

Reference

[1]James, Witten, Hastie, Tibshirani. An Introduction to Statistical Learning, 2015. [2]Paul Jozefek. https://rpubs.com/pjozefek/576206, 2020. [3]risk.net. Quant Finance Masterâ€™s Guide 2022.

Definition 2.68. A set in the plane is called a region if it satisfies the following two conditions: 1. Each point of the set is the center of a circle whose entire interior consists of points of the set. 2. Every two points of the set can be joined by a curve (not a line) which consists entirely of points of the set.

Definition 2.81. The relation \[ f(x,y)=0\tag{2.82} \] defines \(y\) as an implicit function of \(x\) on an interval \(I:a<x<b\), if there exists a function \(g(x)\) defined on \(I\) such that \[ f[x,g(x)]=0\tag{2.83} \] for every \(x\) in \(I\).

Definition 3.4. \(f(x)\) is a solution of the differential equation \[ F(x,y,y',\cdots,y^{(n)})=0\tag{3.41} \]

if

\[ F[x,f(x),f'(x),\cdots,f^{(n)}(x)]=0\tag{3.42} \]

Definition 3.6. A relation \(f(x,y)=0\) will be called an implicit solution of the differential equation

\[F(x,y,y',\cdots,y^{(n)})=0 \tag{3.61}\]

on an interval \(I:a<x<b\), if

  1. it defines \(y\) as an implicit function of \(x\) on \(I\),i.e., if there exists a function \(g(x)\) defined on \(I\) such that \(f[x,g(x)]=0\) for every \(x\) in \(I\), and if

  2. \(g(x)\) satisfies 3.61, i.e., if

\[ F[x,g(x),g'(x),\cdots,g^{(n)}(x)]=0 \tag{3.62} \]

for every \(x\) in \(I\).

Question:

\((e) xy'=2y\leftarrow y=x^2\), \((x\neq 0)\)

\((j)xy'+y=y^2\leftarrow y=\frac{2}{x+2}\), \((x\neq 0,-2)\)

Definition 4.3. The functions defined by

\[ y=f(x,c_1,c_2,\cdots,c_n)\tag{4.31} \]

of the \(n+1\) variables, \(x,c_1,c_2,\cdots,c_n\) will be called an n-parameter family of solutions of the \(n\)th order differential equation

\[F(x,y,y',\cdots,y^{(n)})=0\tag{4.32}\]

if \(\forall c_i(i=1,\cdots,n)\), the resulting function \(f(x)\) defined by \((4.31)\) satisfies \((4.32)\). That is

\[F(x,f,f',\cdots,f^{(n)})=0\tag{4.33}\]

\(n\) order \(\nLeftrightarrow\) \(n\) parameter solutions

\(\nRightarrow\): \((y'')^2+y^2=0\)

\(\nLeftarrow\): \((y'-y)(y'-2y)=0\leftarrow (y-c_1e^x)(y-c_2e^{2x})=0\)

Definition 4.66. particular solution: does not contain arbitrary constants.

Definition 4.7. general solution: contains every particular solution

Definition 4.71. initial conditions: the \(n\) conditions that determine \(c_1,\cdots,c_n\), and given in terms of one value of the independent variable (e.g.ç»™å®š\(t=0\)æ—¶ï¼Œä½ç½®\(x=10\)ï¼Œé€Ÿåº¦\(v=20\))

Definition 5.12. If \(y=f(x)\) or \(f(x,y)=0\) defines \(y\) as a function of \(x\) which satisfies \[y'=F(x,y), \quad a<x<b\tag{5.11}\] then the graph of this function is called an integral curve, it is the graph of a function which is the solution of \((5.11)\).

Remind

\[y'=F(x,y)\Leftrightarrow \text{Direction field}\tag{ODE}\]

\[y(x_0)=y_0 \Leftrightarrow \text{Point}\ (x_0,y_0)\tag{I.C.}\]

\[y(x) \Leftrightarrow \text{Integral curve}\tag{Solution}\]

Definition 5.4. An ordinary point of (5.11) lies on one and only one of its integral curves.

Definition 5.41. A singular point of (5.11) meets two requirements 1. NOT ordinary point: no/more than one integral curve 2. at least one ordinary point \(o_0\in \cup(s_0,\varepsilon),\forall \varepsilon\)

Definition 6.13. Let \(y=f(x)\) define \(y\) as a function of \(x\) on an interval \(I\). The differential of y, written as \(dy\) (or \(df\)) is defined by \[ (dy)(x,\Delta x)=f'(x)\Delta x\tag{6.14} \]

Theorem 6.2. If \(y=x\), then \[(dy)(x,\Delta x)=(dx)(x,\Delta x)=\Delta x\tag{6.22}\]

\(dy\),\(dx\) are differentials, not increment. \(y,x\) after \(d\) are functions, not independent variables

Theorem 6.3. If \(y=f(x)\) defines \(y\) as a function of \(x\) and \(x=g(t)\), \(y=f[g(t)]=F(t)\), define \(x\) and \(y\) as functions of \(t\), then \[(dy)(t,\Delta t)=f'[g(t)][g'(t)(dt)(t,\Delta t)]=f'(x)(dx)(t,\Delta t)\tag{6.31}\]

Definition 6.4. For \(z=f(x,y)\), \[(dz)(x,y,\Delta x,\Delta y)=\frac{\partial f(x,y)}{\partial x}\Delta x+\frac{\partial f(x,y)}{\partial y}\Delta y\tag{6.41}\]

Theorem 6.5. For \(z=f(x,y)\), \(x=x(r,s,\cdots)\),\(y=y(r,s,\cdots)\) \[dz=\frac{\partial f(x,y)}{\partial x}\Delta x+\frac{\partial f(x,y)}{\partial y}\Delta y\tag{6.52}\]

Lecture 1

Complex numbers \(\mathbb{C}\)

\[ (a,b)\quad a,b\in \mathbb{R} \]

Define operations \(+,\cdot\)

  1. \((a,b)+(c,d)=(a+c,b+d)\)

\(\therefore \mathbb{C}\)å½¢æˆä¸€ä¸ª field

denote \((0,1)=i\), \(i^2=-1\), \(x^2+1=0\).

\[ z\in \mathbb{C}\rightarrow z=a+ib \]

\[ f: \Omega\rightarrow \mathbb{C}\quad \Omega\subset \mathbb{C} \]

\[ z_0\in \Omega \]

\(f\) is said to be differentiable at \(z_0\), if \(\displaystyle{\lim_{z\rightarrow z_0}\frac{f(z)-f(z_0)}{z-z_0}}\) exists, denoted by \(f'(z_0)\)

If \(f\) is diff. at every point of \(\Omega\), then we say \(f\) is a holomorphic function ï¼ˆè§£æžå‡½æ•°/å…¨çº¯å‡½æ•°ï¼‰ on \(\Omega\).

\[ O(\Omega)=\{\text{all of the holomorphic functions on }\Omega \} \]

æœ‰\(S\subset \mathbb{C}\) set, \(f\in O(S)\) means, \(f\) is holomorphic on some open neighborhood of \(S\).

\[ \frac{\partial u}{\partial x}(z_0)=\frac{\partial v}{\partial y}(z_0) \]

\[ v(x,y)=\begin{cases} \displaystyle{\frac{x^3+y^3}{x^2+y^2}} & (x,y)\neq (0,0)\\ 0 & (x,y)= (0,0) \end{cases} \]

along \(x=y\) \[ \lim \frac{f(x,x)-f(0,0)}{x+ix}=\frac{ix}{x+ix}=\frac{i}{1+i}=\frac{1+i}{2} \]

If \(f\in C^1(\Omega)\)

\[ \begin{aligned} \frac{\partial f}{\partial \bar{z}} & = \frac 12 \left(\frac{\partial}{\partial x}+i\frac{\partial}{\partial y} \right)(u+iv) \\ &= \frac 12\left (\left (\frac{\partial u}{\partial x}-\frac{\partial v}{\partial y}\right)+i\left(\frac{\partial u}{\partial y}+\frac{\partial v}{\partial x}\right) \right)\\ &=0 \end{aligned} \]

è®²ç‚¹å¾®ç§¯åˆ†ã€‚

\[ s.t. \quad \gamma \text{ is smooth on each }[t_{j-1},t_j], 1\leqslant j\leqslant n \]

Theo (Green)

\(D\) is a bounded domain in \(\mathbb{R}^2\) with piecewise smooth boundary \(\partial D\), let \(P,Q\) be two functions which is \(C^1\) in some open neighborhood of \(\bar{D}\). Assume \(\partial D\) is positively oriented. (æ²¿è¾¹ç•Œèµ°æ—¶domainåœ¨å·¦è¾¹)

Then

\[ \oint_C Pdx+Qdy=\iint_D \left(\frac{\partial Q}{\partial x}-\frac{\partial P}{\partial y} \right)dxdy \]

Theo. Let \(D\) be a simply connected domain in \(\mathbb{C}\)

Suppose \(f\in C^1(D)\), then \[ f\in O(D)\Leftrightarrow \oint_{\tau} f(z)dz=0 \]

for every piecewise smooth simple closed curve \(\tau\) in \(D\)

simply connected è¯´æ˜Žä¸¤ä»¶äº‹ 1. arcwise connectedï¼š ä»»ä½•ä¸¤ä¸ªç‚¹éƒ½èƒ½ç”¨arcè¿žèµ·æ¥ 2. \(\pi_1(D)=0\)ï¼š domainå†…æ¯ä¸ªå°é—­æ›²çº¿éƒ½èƒ½ç¼©æˆä¸€ä¸ªç‚¹ï¼ˆæ²¡æœ‰æ´žï¼‰

\(\Omega\): region surrounded by \(\Gamma\).

\[ \begin{aligned} \oint_{\Gamma} f(z)dz & = \oint_{\Gamma}f(z)(dx+idy) \\ & = \iint_{\Omega}\left(i\frac{\partial f}{\partial x}-\frac{\partial f}{\partial y}\right)dxdy \\ & = i\iint_{\Omega}\left(\frac{\partial f}{\partial x}+i\frac{\partial f}{\partial y}\right)dxdy \\ & = 2i\iint_{\Omega}\frac{\partial f}{\partial \bar{z}}dxdy \end{aligned} \]

\[ \oint_{\Gamma} f(z)dz=0\Leftrightarrow \frac{\partial f}{\partial \bar{z}}=0\ on\ D.\ \blacksquare \]

Lecture 2

Theo : (Cauchy's integral formula) Let \(D\) be a bounded domain in \(\mathbb{C}\) with piecewise smooth doundary. Suppose \(f\in C^1(\bar{D})\), Then \[ f(w)=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\oint_{\partial D}\frac{f(z)}{z-w}dw-\frac{1}{\pi}\iint_D \frac{\displaystyle{\frac{\partial f}{\partial \bar{z}}}(z)}{z-w}dxdy,\quad \forall w\in D \]

where \(z=x+iy\).

consider \(D_{\varepsilon}=D/\bar{B_{\varepsilon}}\), \(B_{\epsilon}=B(w;\epsilon)\)

æŒ–æŽ‰åœ†ç›˜åŽæœ‰å†…å¤–ä¸¤ä¸ªè¾¹ç•Œï¼Œæ›²çº¿ç§¯åˆ†ç­‰äºŽå¤–å›´çš„å‡å†…å›´çš„

\[ \begin{aligned} \oint_{\partial D_{\epsilon}}\frac{f(z)}{z-w}dz&=2i\iint_{D_{\epsilon}}\frac{\partial}{\partial \bar{z}}\left(\frac{f(z)}{z-w}\right)dxdy \\ &=2i\iint_{D_{\epsilon}}\frac{\frac{\partial f}{\partial \bar{z}}(z)}{z-w}dxdy \quad \star \end{aligned} \]

\[ \oint_{\partial D_{\epsilon}}\frac{f(z)}{z-w}dz=\oint_{\partial D}\frac{f(z)}{z-w}dz-\oint_{\partial B_{\epsilon}}\frac{f(z)}{z-w}dz \quad \star \]

set \(z=w+\epsilon e^{i\theta}\), \(z-w=\epsilon e^{i\theta}\)

\[ \begin{aligned} \oint_{\partial B_{\epsilon}}\frac{f(z)}{z-w}dz&=\oint_{\partial B_{\epsilon}}\frac{f(w+\epsilon e^{i\theta})}{\epsilon e^{i\theta}}dz\\ &=\int_0^{2\pi} \frac{f(w+\epsilon e^{i\theta})}{\epsilon e^{i\theta}}i\epsilon e^{i\theta}d\theta\\ &=i\int_0^{2\pi}f(w+\epsilon e^{i\theta})d\theta\\ &\xrightarrow{\epsilon\rightarrow0} i\int_0^{2\pi}f(w)d\theta\\ &=2\pi if(w) \end{aligned} \]

ä¸‹é¢è€ƒè™‘è¿™ä¸ªç§¯åˆ†

\[ 2i\iint_{D_{\epsilon}}\frac{\frac{\partial f}{\partial \bar{z}}(z)}{z-w}dxdy \]

å› ä¸º\(f\)æ˜¯\(C^1\)å‡½æ•°ï¼Œ\(\frac{\partial f}{\partial \bar{z}}(z)\in C(\bar{D})\)

let \(\epsilon\rightarrow 0\)

\[ \oint_{\partial D}\frac{f(z)}{z-w}dz-2\pi if(w)=2i\iint_{D}\frac{\frac{\partial f}{\partial \bar{z}}(z)}{z-w}dxdy \]

\[ \therefore f(w)=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\oint_{\partial D}\frac{f(z)}{z-w}dw-\frac{1}{\pi}\iint_D \frac{\displaystyle{\frac{\partial f}{\partial \bar{z}}}(z)}{z-w}dxdy\quad \blacksquare \]

Theo Let \(D\subset \mathbb{C}\) be a simply-connected domain, suppose \(f\in C^1(D)\cap O(D)\). Then \[ f(w)=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\oint_{\partial D}\frac{f(z)}{z-w}dw\quad w\in \Omega \]

\(\Omega\): region surrounded by the simple closed curve \(C\)

simply connected æ˜¯ä¸ºäº†ä¿è¯\(C\)å›´å‡ºæ¥çš„è¿˜åœ¨\(D\)é‡Œé¢ï¼Œé¿å…ä¸‹é¢è¿™ç§æƒ…å†µ

Theo (Cauchys)

Let \(D\) be a simply connected domain in \(\mathbb{C}\),

\(C\): simple closed curve in \(D\)

If \(f\in O(D)\). Then

\[ \oint_C f(z)dz=0 \]

ä¹‹å‰æœ‰\(C^1\)æ˜¯ä¸ºäº†è¯‰è¯¸äºŽæ ¼æž—å®šç†ï¼Œä½†è¯æ˜Žè¿™ä¸ªå®šç†ä¸èƒ½ç”¨æ ¼æž—ï¼Œè¦ç”¨å®Œå…¨ä¸åŒçš„æƒ³æ³•

\(R\): rectangle

Claim: \(\oint_{\partial R}f(z)dz=0\)

åè¯æ³•

Assume \(\exists R\) s.t. \[ \oint_{\partial R}f(z)dz=A\neq 0 \]

åˆ‡å‰²ï¼Œå¯¹å¤§é•¿æ–¹å½¢ç§¯ä¸€æ¬¡ï¼Œç›¸å½“äºŽå¯¹å››ä¸ªå°é•¿æ–¹å½¢å„ç§¯ä¸€æ¬¡

\[ \oint_Rf(z)dz=\sum_{k=1}^4\oint_{R^{(k)}}f(z)dz \]

\[ \therefore \exists R_1=R^{(j)} \ \text{some }j, \quad s.t. \bigg|\oint_{\partial R_1}f(z)dz \bigg|\geq \frac{A}{4} \]

\[ \bigg|\oint_{\partial R_2}f(z)dz \bigg|\geq \frac{A}{4^2} \]

obtain a seq. of rectangle \(\{R_n\}\)

\[ \bigg|\oint_{\partial R_n}f(z)dz \bigg|\geq \frac{A}{4^n} \]

By Cantor intersection theorem \[ \exists P_0\in R_n, \ \forall n\quad P_0\in D \]

Write near \(P_0\)

\[ f(z)=f(P_0)+f'(P_0)(z-P_0)+\epsilon (z)(z-P_0) \]

n å¾ˆå¤§æ—¶ï¼Œ\(f(z)\)å¯ä»¥ç”¨\(f(P_0)+f'(P_0)(z-P_0)+\epsilon (z)(z-P_0)\)æ›¿æ¢

\[ \oint_{\partial R_n}\left[f(P_0)+f'(P_0)(z-P_0)+\epsilon (z)(z-P_0)\right]dz \]

å¤šé¡¹å¼ä¸€å®šæ˜¯æŸä¸ªå‡½æ•°çš„å¾®åˆ†ï¼Œ \[ \therefore f(P_0)+f'(P_0)(z-P_0)=Q'(z) \]

\(Q(z)\): polynomial of degree at most 2

\(z=\gamma(t)\)

\[ \begin{aligned} &\oint_{\partial R_n}[f(P_0)+f'(P_0)(z-P_0)]dz\\ =&\oint_{\partial R_n}Q'(z)dz\\ =&\int_a^bQ'(z)\gamma'(t)dt\\ =&\int_a^bd(Q(z))\\ =& Q(\gamma(b))-Q(\gamma(a))=0\quad \text{é¦–å°¾ç›¸è¿ž} \end{aligned} \]

å› ä¸º \[ |\oint_{\partial R_n}dz|=|\int_a^b\gamma'(t)dt|\leq \int_a^b|\gamma'(t)|dt=Ln \] \((z-P_0)\)å°äºŽç­‰äºŽ\(Ln\)ï¼ˆå¼¦é•¿å°äºŽç­‰äºŽç›´å¾„ï¼‰ï¼Œ\(dz\)ç§¯åˆ†ä¹Ÿå°äºŽ\(Ln\)ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥ä¸¤æ¬¡ã€‚\(\epsilon\)ç”¨æœ€å¤§å€¼æå‡ºæ¥ \[ \begin{aligned} &|\oint_{\partial R_n}\left[f(P_0)+f'(P_0)(z-P_0)+\epsilon (z)(z-P_0)\right]dz|\\ =&|\oint_{\partial R_n}\epsilon (z)(z-P_0)dz|\\ \leq &\max_{z\in \partial R_n}|\epsilon(z)|\cdot L_n^2 \end{aligned} \]

ç”±äºŽ \(\displaystyle{L_n=\frac{L}{2^n}}\)

\[ \max_{z\in \partial R_n}|\epsilon(z)|\cdot \left(\frac{L}{2^n}\right)^2\geq \frac{|A|}{4^n} \]

å½“\(n\rightarrow \infty\)æ—¶ï¼Œ\(\max_{z\in \partial R_n}|\epsilon(z)|\rightarrow 0\)

\[ \therefore \max_{z\in \partial R_n}|\epsilon(z)|\geq \frac{|A|}{L^2}\Rightarrow 0\geq \frac{|A|}{L^2}\quad \text{çŸ›ç›¾}.\ \square \]

entry.title: ç‰¹æ®Šå¾®åˆ†æ–¹ç¨‹çš„è§£
entry.content:
Separable Variables

å½“\(x,y\)å¯åˆ†ç¦»æ—¶ï¼Œ \[ Q(x,y)\frac{dy}{dx}+P(x,y)=0\tag{6.6} \] \[ P(x,y)dx+Q(x,y)dy=0\tag{6.61} \] \[ \Rightarrow f(x)dx+g(y)dy=0\tag{6.62} \] \[ \Rightarrow \int f(x)dx+\int g(y)dy=C\tag{6.63} \]

Def 7.1 Let \(z=f(x,y)\) define \(z\) as a function of \(x\) and \(y\) in a region \(R\). The function \(f(x,y)\) is said to be homogeneous of order n if it can be written as

\[ f(x,y)=x^ng(u)\tag{7.11} \]

where \(u=\dfrac yx\) and \(g(u)\) is a function of \(u\); or alternately if it can be written as

\[ f(x,y)=y^nh(u)\tag{7.11} \]

where \(u=\dfrac xy\) and \(h(u)\) is a function of \(u\)

ä¹Ÿå¯å®šä¹‰ä¸ºï¼šA function \(f(x,y)\) is said to be homogeneous of order n if \[f(tx,ty)=t^nf(x,y)\tag{7.16}\]

Homogeneous Coefficients

Definition 7.2. The differential equation \[P(x,y)dx+Q(x,y)dy=0\tag{7.3}\] where \(P(x,y)\) and \(Q(x,y)\) are each homogeneous functions of order \(n\) is called a first order differential equation with homogeneous coefficients.

Theorem 7.32. If the coefficients in \((7.3)\) are each homogeneous function of order \(n\), then the substitution in it of \((7.31),(7.33)\) will lead to an equation in which the variables are separable.

\[y=ux\ \Leftarrow \ \left(u=\frac{y}{x}\right),\quad dy=udx+xdu,\quad \tag{7.31}\]

\[x=uy\ \Leftarrow \ \left(u=\frac{x}{y}\right),\quad dx=udy+ydu,\quad \tag{7.33}\]

Def 9.23 \[ P(x,y)dx+Q(x,y)dy\tag{9.24} \] is called an exact differential if it is the total differential of a function \(f(x,y)\). \[ P(x,y)=\frac{\partial}{\partial x}f(x,y)\quad Q(x,y)=\frac{\partial}{\partial y}f(x,y)\tag{9.241} \]

Def 9.27 \[ P(x,y)dx+Q(x,y)dy\tag{9.28}=0 \] is called exact differential equation if follows \((9.241)\).

Theorem 9.3. A necessary and sufficient condition that the differential equation \[ P(x,y)dx+Q(x,y)dy\tag{9.31}=0 \] be exact is that \[ \frac{\partial}{\partial y}P(x,y)=\frac{\partial}{\partial x}Q(x,y\tag{9.32}) \]

\((10.28)\) \(ye^{xy}dx+xe^{xy}dy=0\) \(e^{xy}=c\)

Integrating Factor

Def 10.5 A multiplying factor which converts an inexact diff eq into an exact one is called integrating factor.

\[ \frac{\partial}{\partial y}[hP(x,y)]=\frac{\partial}{\partial x}[hQ(x,y)]\tag{10.62 $\star$} \]

  1. \(h=h(x)\)

\[ \frac{dh(x)}{h(x)}=\frac{\frac{\partial}{\partial y}P(x,y)-\frac{\partial}{\partial x}Q(x,y)}{Q(x,y)}dx\tag{10.64} \]

æ›´ç‰¹æ®Šåœ°ï¼Œ\(F(x)=\displaystyle{\frac{\frac{\partial}{\partial y}P(x,y)-\frac{\partial}{\partial x}Q(x,y)}{Q(x,y)}}\)ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥\(\displaystyle{h(x)=e^{\int F(x)dx}}\)

  1. \(h=h(y)\)

\[ \frac{dh(y)}{h(y)}=\frac{\frac{\partial}{\partial x}Q(x,y)-\frac{\partial}{\partial y}P(x,y)}{P(x,y)}dy\tag{10.68} \]

  1. \(h=h(u), u=xy\)

\[ \frac{dh(u)}{h(u)}=\frac{\frac{\partial}{\partial y}P(x,y)-\frac{\partial}{\partial x}Q(x,y)}{yQ(x,y)-xP(x,y)}du\tag{10.72} \]

  1. \(h=h(u),u=\frac xy\) \[ \frac{dh(u)}{h(u)}=\frac{y^2\left[\frac{\partial}{\partial y}P(x,y)-\frac{\partial}{\partial x}Q(x,y)\right]}{xP(x,y)+yQ(x,y)}du\tag{10.76} \]

  2. \(h=h(u),u=\frac yx\)

\[ \frac{dh(u)}{h(u)}=\frac{x^2\left[\frac{\partial}{\partial x}Q(x,y)-\frac{\partial}{\partial y}P(x,y)\right]}{xP(x,y)+yQ(x,y)}du\tag{10.76} \]

Linear DE

Def 11.1 A linear diff eq of the first order is \[ \frac{dy}{dx}+P(x)y=Q(x)\tag{11.11} \]

Integrating factor is in the form \(\displaystyle{e^{\int P(x)dx}}\), by \((9.32)\).

\[ \left[P(x)e^{\int P(x)dx}y-Q(x)e^{\int P(x)dx}\right]dx+e^{\int P(x)dx}dy=0\tag{11.13} \]

\[ \underbrace{e^{\int P(x)dx}dy+P(x)e^{\int P(x)dx}ydx}_{d(e^{\int P(x)dx}y)}=Q(x)e^{\int P(x)dx}dx\tag{11.16} \]

\[ e^{\int P(x)dx}dy=\int Q(x)e^{\int P(x)dx}dx+C\tag{11.19} \]

This is a true general solution of \((11.11)\). \[ y=e^{-\int P(x)dx}\int Q(x)e^{\int P(x)dx}dx+Ce^{-\int P(x)dx}\tag{11.191} \]
